Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research on dynamic auction markets. Auctions are used to buy and sell many important goods and services; these market environments include electricty markets, financial markets, public procurement, and a wide range of e-commerce applications. The firms and customers participating in these markets usually make many purchases and sales; this means that dynamic behavior is an important feature of these markets. Understanding these dynamics both in and out of market equilibrium is an important and open challenge.

The PI seeks first to develop new mathematical models of these markets and will then use data from actual auction markets to formally test the models. The hope is that by iterating between theory and data he will create a new category of tools that are well-tested and can be employed by other researchers interested in studying markets with these features. The empirical analysis includes data from two different kinds of markets: ecommerce auctions for cameras sold through eBay and electricity markets in Great Britain.

This project has important broader impacts. The results will be useful for competition authorities who seek to understand the dynamic concerns facing buyers and sellers in auction markets. The methods developed here may also be useful for analyzing dynamic behavior in non-auction markets. For example, the third project is about how firms adjust their behavior after a policy change, and the results will be valuable to electricity regulators who need to consider how US firms will adjust to proposed 'smart grid' policies and technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project endeavored to extend existing methods in the empirical auctions literature by incorporating dynamic concerns that are salient for real auction participants. By doing so we hope to understand auction marketplaces as marketplaces, i.e. a dynamic environment with competing substitutes and persistent players rather than, as the literature has historically, a sequence of independent, static games with transient participants.

Understanding the dynamics of auction marketplaces is important for the design and regulation of auction markets, as well as for participants.  How should a large seller set reserve prices or stagger auctions, when they affect not only outcomes today, but the dynamics of the market? And understanding that, how should a competition authority think about the exertion of market power by large sellers? How does search affect auction outcomes in a dynamic marketplace? And how do participants learn to play when we change the rules? The methods developed in this project are directly useful for answering these questions.

Three research papers came about under the umbrella of this project.

1. "Dynamic Demand Estimation in Auction Markets" (formerly "An Estimable Demand System for a Large Auction Platform Market") developed new methods for estimating consumer preferences using data from auction markets where the items for sale are heterogeneous and there are many purchase opportunities, so that losing an auction today preserves the option value of participating in another tomorrow.  Joint work between Matt Backus and Greg Lewis. (revisions underway for the Review of Economic Studies).

2. "Just Starting Out: Learning and Price Competition in the British Electricity Market" examines convergence to an equilibrium and learning among players bidding in a newly opened, dynamic auction environment pursuant to the deregulation of the frequency response market in the UK.  Joint work between Ulrich Doraszelski, Greg Lewis, and Ariel Pakes. (published at the American Economic Review).

3. "Who Benefits from Improved Search?" examines how platforms can mediate prices and allocations in an auction marketplace by changing search costs and defaults.  Joint work between Greg Lewis, Gleb Romanyuk, and Albert Wang.
